newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia pepper seen firm from lower output in '97.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia pepper seen firm from lower output in '97.

text.p: Malaysia's pepper market looks bullish in the near term, with a lower crop in the current year lending support to prices, traders said on Thursday.

White pepper out of the east Malaysian state of Sarawak -- the country's main pepper producing area -- was quoted between $5,100 and $5,200 a tonne in the New York market for July/August shipment, lower than the high of $5,842 at the end of March.
But black pepper from Sarawak was trading at around $3,900 a tonne in New York for July/August, compared to $3,483 at end-March, traders said.
In Malaysia, Sarawak black pepper was fetching around 7,000 ringgit a tonne for July/August, compared to 6,660 ringgit between January and March, traders said.
They said white pepper from Sarawak was quoted at around 1,100 ringgit for July/August, compared to a high of 1,178 ringgit in the first quarter of the year.

"Basically, the market is strong on the fundamental side," said a spokesman for the Pepper Marketing Board in Sarawak. "We're seeing a good run now for black pepper compared to white, but that's only a matter of preference."
Malaysian prices will be supported this year by a lower production of around 12,000 to 15,000 tonnes of pepper, compared to 20,239 tonnes in 1996, the spokesman said.
Growers expect production to decline because there has been more rain than last year.
"The export figures may, however, vary as stocks that are held for more than a year are sometimes released into the market," he added.
The pepper board said production in the first quarter of 1997 was 5,493 tonnes.
Malaysia is among the world's top five pepper producers, along with India, Indonesia, Vietnam and Brazil.
